comments.commentBody:
I find myself in agreement with Zoot, wondering how many journalists, with or without legal background, have carefully read the opinion and dissent before writing their articles. A careful reading of the opinion can lead to no other conclusion but a complete Supreme Court repudiation of the Arizona law. In fact, the heart of the law has not been upheld. The right of Federal law to govern State law in cases of immigration is clearly defined and reaffirmed. In fact, if a person is held by a state for immigration infraction alone, that state will be held liable for any of the punishments flowing from civil rights violations.

What is astonishing is Scalia's dissent--a document that reads like a screed penned by Calhoun.

What opinion are you folks reading? The court did not uphold section 2(B) in the way you suggest. One of the biggest fears reported was that this section would be used to jail people while their status in the country was casually checked, leaving them to languish in jail for days. The court said no to that type detention: "Detaining individuals solely to verify their immigration status would raise constitutional concerns." More importantly, the court made it clear that Arizona cannot act under this provision without federal supervision: "And it would disrupt the federal framework to put state officers in the position of holding aliens in custody for possible unlawful presence without federal direction and supervision." Given everything else the opinion says about the necessity of federal discretion in its immigration policies, this statement guts Arizona's authority to do what it seemed to want to do with its statute.

The bottom line is the court told Arizona it needs to operate with a very narrow focus and objective in using this statute, because as it concluded, "This opinion does not foreclose other preemption and constitutional challenges to the law as interpreted and applied after it goes into effect."

What the court did with respect to the section unanimously upheld by the eight Justices who heard the case isn't terribly complicated. They held in effect that the area which the statute purported to cover was not preempted by federal law. Obviously, if the Arizona courts interpret the Law in a way that would render it unconstitutional for some reason e.g. racial profiling, the lawwill be struck down for that reason but not because the Arizona law was preempted by federal law. Arizona will then be free to amend its law to comply with constitutional requirements.

This section upheld by a unanimous court was held to be not unconstitutional and was not preempted by federal law. There was no division along philosophical lines here. For that we should be thankful.

It really is time to discuss term limits for Supreme Court Justices. Scalia has really gone around the bend this time. Obnoxious arrogance and ill-disguised contempt for the Constitution coupled with his total lack of respect for the office of the President suggests that he is either delusional or megalomaniacal - either way it's time for him to retire.

Whatever the calculations or conclusions, a prospective college student should understand that he or she will become a paying customer who is handing over money (mostly student loan) to a program that only exists because there is a market for it — not because the world actually needs another 15,000 reporters or 34.000 marine biologists or 48.000 historians 4 years from now.  Too many of us think that the number of programs is somehow scaled to the number of jobs that are available to all the graduates out there. As long as students/parents are willing to pay, higher education institutions will be there to collect their money/student loan.  Whether this bubble bursts depends on whether Americans wise up to this hidden truth.
He's coming to Boston for three shows in August Diana, two at Fenway and one in Foxboro. Go see one of these shows. It's not another person's fantasy world. It's our reality he sings about.
Yes, all true art speaks in the particular but appeals universally.  Brooks again gives us dense prose and muddled thought.

I think I have a very different experience of what's described here.  I have a really hard time with other people's detailed fantasy worlds but I love particular images or moments a songwriter or novelist presents, and often they seem like doors to other images or ideas, as if i can see through what the artist presents to something else that, at least for me, lies behind it.  The narratives I tend not to be able to get into, and I have put aside Rowling, Tolkien, and Lewis for similar reasons, but I like the themes and concepts in the books.  For me, maybe, the particular is a gateway to the universal, not a destination in itself.

This is a black eye for GM.

It’s the car’s fifth recall since it arrived in showrooms nearly two years ago, and marks the second time that GM had to recall every Cruze it had made, up to the point that the defect was found.

About a year ago, GM had to recall all Cruzes to address some steering and transmission problems. That came on the tails of a small recall aimed at making sure the steering wheel wouldn't just, you know, fall off.

I was the happy owner of a '67 GTO and yes I also had an EIGHT-TRACK stereo hanging from under the dashboard...In the 'I only got them thanks to the crosses DEPTS.', TORII leads the parade closely followed by GELID, PALAU and NEY...OMAHA and ETHAN are two for two this week. Yesterday they were intersecting. Today they have drifted apart a bit. It was a bit EERIE to see ERIE in the grid with its' scary cousin... A NICE easy-goer from Mike Torch on the last Tuesday of June. WHAT GOES on with the EMERGEnce of Wednesday's puzzle is anybody's guess. I guess I HAVE to wait a day to find out.
H ow EERIE that you read my mind across all this distance.

The Constitution does not grant rights to "cooperative endeavors". It grants rights to INDIVIDUALS, and it was written that way because the founders wanted a country where cooperative endeavors of all kinds, both corporate and religious, would not be allowed to infringe on anyone's individual liberty. Any rights assigned to a group are derived from the rights of the individuals in that group, who have the right to grant or withdraw their support freely at any time.

One thing that has made our govt work is the concept of distribution of powers and checks and balances. Money is power, and when it's distributed in a grossly unequal manner, and the individual has no power to counter its effects, then we tilt the balance in favor of oligarchy.
The best that money can buy? If only we got our money's worth!

Addendum:

Anthony Scalia writing a discenting opinion in the Arizona "Papers Please Law",
"If securing it's territory in this fashion is not within the power of Arizona, we should cease referring to it as a sovereign state."
He clearly believed in states rights in this instance, but on the same day he ruled against the Montana campaign financing laws(states's rights?) indicating that the states have no rights in this matter. May we now and forever stop believing in this court's impartiality.

Unions need explicit consent only from nonmembers who, one would suppose, are not entitled to vote in union elections even though they must pay dues for union representation in labor/management issues.  Common shareholders in a publicly held corporation typically get one vote for each owned share, and owners of nonvoting shares knew that going in.  Corporations do not have a disenfranchised class comparable to the unions' class of nonmember employees.
The ATB party would not need a corporation do do this; the added complexity adds nothing essential.
How come our leaders show no interest in passing legislation to achieve what the Supreme Court cannot?
I'm reluctant to refer to people as evil but the Citizens United group comes close, very very close.
I just wish they would vote their conscience rather than political party. It's not right that it seems it is to often 5 to 4. I'm sure that was not the intent of the founding fathers.
Interesting that the Court decided FOR states' rights in the Arizona case and AGAINST states' rights re the Montana law. Is this their way of showing impartiality?

Do lawless, constitution-hating, leftist political activists like Ginsburg, Breyer, Sotomayor and Kagan support restrictions on the billions and billions and billions of unregulated and unlimited dollars spent (every year!) campaigning for Democrats and producing reliably, consistently false, bogus attack ads against Republicans by these virulent, militant, fundamentalist, extremist, leftist Super PACs like ABC, NBC, CBS, PBS, NPR, CNN, A-Mess-NBC, ESPN, HBO, Showtime, the New York Times-Democrat, the Washington Post-Democrat, the execrable Associated (with terrorists) Press, al Reuters, al Jazeera, al McClatchy, et al.?  If not, on what basis do they oppose such restrictions on the amount of money spent by the aforesaid virulent, leftist Super PACs?
But if you're white, you won't be stopped unless you are breaking the law. Anyone who looks Hispanic will be stopped for driving while Hispanic.

Same old, same old from people like you.  No one advocating comprehensive immigration reform says it is okay for people to illegally come to live in the U.S.  In order to get in the immigration line, all the reformers require that would-be citizens or green card holders have to learn English, pay fines, and not have a criminal record.
7 million illegal aliens hold jobs - where is the compassion for minority, unskilled US citizens and legal immigrants who are unemployed as a result?   Illegal immigration is NOT a victimless crime.

The best part of the decision was Justice Scalia's dissenting opinion.

Three administrations ignored our immigration laws and allowed perhaps 20 million people to come here ilegally--two Bushes and clinton. Now we have a President who is "changing" statutory law by executive order--Barack Obama.

The majority opinion does not give us any power over the treasonous conduct of these officials except impeachment. And Congress refuses to take that action.

We are powerless to protect our borders, society, and jobs in our own country because of this ruling.

I now expect the court to approve Obamacare, as well.
Would have loved to know the actual phrasing of the question

Large is L =50
Extra Large is XL = 40
Extra Extra Large is XXL =30

It's funny that he gave you this puzzle, because last time I saw Dr. Knuth he asked me "Where is large bigger than extra large?" although probably he had some cleverer phrasing of that question/joke/puzzle.

The role of Supreme Court Justice requires an individual who is capable of making impartial judgements based on the laws of the United States. Much like a referee of a sporting event the Justice should be able to make a decision based on the rules no matter what their personal bias may be. That Scalia chose to use his office as a public forum for making political commentary on an issue that was not before the court is highly inappropriate and demonstrates that he lacks the judicial temperament that is essential for a Justice of the Supreme Court. If he is unable to restrain himself from making such unsolicited political comments it would be advisable for him to resign his present position and seek employment at Fox News where such behavior is considered to be the acceptable norm.
